message:
My suggestion to the "Israeli officials": transparency!

Get out from behind the curtain. Present to the public the proposal to which you agreed and present the proposal to which Hamas agreed.

The Israeli public has the right to see the details of a deal that will affect their future in the State of Israel and judge for themselves.
event_breakdown: No specific events are mentioned in the text. The text suggests a proposal or deal involving Israeli officials and Hamas, but it does not provide a location or describe a specific event that can be placed on a map.

message:
A senior Hamas official told the American CBS network about the negotiations in Cairo:

No progress was made in the current round of talks on Saturday.
Another round will be held on Sunday (today).

###
According to Al-Arabiya, Hamas requested an additional period of time to examine some of the clauses before giving its final answer to the proposal.
event_breakdown:
- Negotiations in Cairo between Hamas and other parties
- Hamas requests additional time to examine clauses of a proposal

message:
From Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu's statement, a short time ago:

"...Surrendering to the demands of Hamas would be a terrible defeat for the State of Israel.
It will be a huge victory for Hamas, for Iran, for the entire "axis of evil".
It will project a terrible weakness - both to our allies and to our enemies.
And this weakness will only bring the next war closer, and it will push the next peace agreement further away. Because alliances are not made with the weak and defeated, alliances are made with the strong and victorious.

Therefore, Israel will not agree to Hamas's demands, which mean surrender, and will continue fighting until all its goals are achieved."

###
Netanyahu announces in his voice publicly: the fighting will continue.

Now we wait to see how Hamas reacts to this, and how this statement will affect the talks in Cairo.
event_breakdown:
- Netanyahu announces that Israel will not agree to Hamas's demands
- Netanyahu states that surrendering to Hamas would be a terrible defeat for Israel
- Netanyahu believes surrender to Hamas would be a victory for Hamas, Iran, and the "axis of evil"
- Netanyahu warns that surrendering would project weakness to allies and enemies
- Netanyahu expresses that weakness will bring the next war closer and push peace agreements further away
- Netanyahu emphasizes that Israel will continue fighting until all its goals are achieved

message:
The Egyptian Foreign Ministry condemns the operation in Rafah. But what does it really mean?

The Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs: 

"We strongly condemn the Israeli actions in Rafah and the takeover of the Palestinian side of the Rafah crossing. Egypt sees this as a risk to the lives of more than a million Palestinians who rely on the crossing. We call on Israel to exercise maximum restraint and "stay away from the edge of the precipice" - as it harms the efforts to reach a Hudna.

###
An untrained reader might wrongly think that Egypt truly opposes an Israeli military action in Rafah. I mean, it strongly condemned it...

But if we dig a little deeper, translate it into "spoken Middle Eastern", and read between the lines - there is no threat of concrete actions from the Egyptian side, no threat to trade agreements, or diplomatic relations, and certainly not to the peace agreements between the two countries.  

Egypt calls on Israel to exercise maximum restraint... This translates to - When you take down Hamas in Rafah, do it in a way that won't make us look bad. After all, we're not really doing anything to prevent you from doing so, but we still need to maintain our image as one of the leading countries in the Arab world...

The al-Sisi regime, which despises the Muslim Brotherhood and its Palestinian branch - Hamas, would be more than happy to see Hamas disappear from its border.

Meanwhile, there are quite a few complaints among Gazans on social media: Where has the Egyptian army gone? They're doing nothing to prevent Israel from acting in Rafah...

##
To summarize, the Egyptians are not that excited, and Hamas has not stopped the ceasefire talks. Now we understand just how idle all the threats to prevent a military operation in Rafah were.

This is an important lesson for the coming months of the war.
location: My knowledge is based on information available up to 2022, and I cannot provide real-time updates. However, as of my last update, the group Hamas is considered a terrorist organization by a number of countries and organizations, including the United States, Israel, the European Union, and Canada, among others.

message:
Fatah supporters on Facebook mock Hamas by publishing a "newly-updated list" (instead of the existing one planned for today) of those approved to leave Gaza through the Rafah crossing today, which includes the following Israeli names:

كشوفات تنسيقات شركة هلا ليوم 7 مايو على معبر رفح

-ديفيد سمحون David Simhon
-دانيال نفتالي Daniel Naftali 
- شمعون رادان Shimon Radan
- سابير مزراحي Sapir Mizrachi
- شوشان حاران Shoshan Haran
event_breakdown: - Fatah supporters mock Hamas on Facebook by publishing a "newly-updated list" of approved individuals to leave Gaza through the Rafah crossing, including Israeli names.

message:
I have no grand words to write to you for Holocaust Day.

Just this: be good to each other. Look for what unites us. This is the secret of our strength. Together we can do anything. Against all of our enemies. This week, between Holocaust Day and Memorial Day, write only good things. No hate, no loathing. And if it's difficult then you can not write anything at all. It will only do you and all of us good.
event_breakdown:
1. Holocaust Day commemoration event
- Location: Various locations around the world

2. Memorial Day observance event
- Location: Various locations around the world

3. Call for unity and kindness
- Location: Not specified

4. Encouragement to focus on positive messages
- Location: Not specified

5. Request to refrain from hate and negativity
- Location: Not specified
